SCOPE Publishes Projects List
Under CORE, SOS Sponsors
For Summer Project Workers
By GARTH MacKENZIE
In the past five years a constantly increasing number of
college students have become involved in community service
projects throughout the United
States.
Student organizations on
American campuses are beginning to demonstrate a greater
concern for the social, economic,
and political affairs of the country and its citizens, as compared
to the general apathy which existed in the schools a decade ago.
This summer, under the auspices of organizations such as
the Congress for Racial Equality,
Students for a Democratic Society, the American Friends Service Committee, and the National
Catholic
Welfare
Conference,
college students will be serving
communities as social workers,
tutors, and guides.
In order to provide an authoratative, impartial journal listing
the opportunities available to
students wishing to work in

Research Opportunities
for EE's and ME's
The U.S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery
& auxiliary systems (electrical, propulsion, control, etc.). In addition to developing basic improvements
in performance and reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on ship silencing, new concepts in energy conversion and control, ways to minimize friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels;
and tough, resistant naval alloys to meet all ocean environmental conditions.
The Laboratory buildings—now more than 50 of them—house some of the finest research, experimental
and evaluation equipments of their kind ... such as high-speed computers, electric power generators, vibration and shock test stands, metals composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities,
physics and chemistry labs, and complex instrumentation for measuring strain, stress, pressure, acceleration,
velocity, performance, and reliability. The Laboratory grounds resemble a modern industrial park, and
include special facilities for in-field experimentation.
Because of a sharply increased workload involving urgent new projects, there are key openings for qualified professionals in every MEL division ... Electrical Systems, Machinery Systems, Ship Silencing, Friction St Wear, Naval Alloys, and Special Projects.

Mechanical Engineers—Research and development in shipboard propulsion machinery ... pneumatic and hydraulic systems ... friction and
'sear equipment and devices ... machinery silencing ... and many other
naval and shipboard mechanical applications.
Electrical Engineers—Research and development in electrical power and
its control ... magnetic fields ... ship control systems ... instrumentation ...
electro-chemical processes ... electro/electro-mechanical equipment silencing
... plus a variety of additional naval and shipboard electrical applications.
Electronic Engineers—Research and development in electronics...
servo-mechanisms ... electro/mechanical devices ... instrument and panel
illuminations ... pressure measurement ... fluid flow measurement.
The starting salary for graduates with a BS degree is $5,990 or $7,050 depending on individual scholastic
qualifications. For those graduates with an advanced degree, correspondingly higher beginning salaries are
available. Every position includes the complete benefits of Career Civil Service and regular increases in
grade. All applicants will be considered on an equal opportunity basis and relocation expenses will be paid.
If you are interested in applying your capabilities to the vital and expanding business of improving ship and
submarine performance, write to Mr. W. M. Siesko, Head-Employment Branch, (Code 162-CN)

The American Way
The Johnson Administration has adopted the nasty
habit of presenting United States' activities on the world
scene as faits accomplis. The President is supposedly
sensitive to campus opinion, but it is now often hard for
even resourceful students and professors to get facts to
have opinions about. When they finally do get them,
they are no longer applicable to the situation.
Who knows the Administration's rationale for
bombing North Vietnam? It used to be because the North
was actively aiding the Viet Cong in the South (a contention our Government attempted to prove after the
raids began) and this was a measure to curtail that aid.
Today the Administration admits that the raids are of
minimal value in performing this function. Who knows
what the current reason is? The Marines went into
Santo Domingo with the avowed intention of establishing
a demilitarized zone to protect our citizens. This itself,
humane though it might be, is a violation of the OAS
Charter the United States so enthusiastically promoted.
Within a week our forces had moved out of this zone
into direct confrontation with the rebels. Why was this
done?
The question of who is right in Vietnam or Santo
Domingo is not at issue here. What is at issue is how a
democratic government justifies partially or wholly
concealing basic policies from its citzens. What is the
purpose of delaying the public announcement of motives
and non-secret facts (e.g. Communists have taken over
the Dominican revolution) until after the die is cast?
It is very dangerous to have history written even a
week in advance.

Old Glory
Fraternity pranks are normally of a fairly innocuous
nature and can he condoned as one of the traditions,
either positive or negative, of the fraternity pledge
period. Whn the whimsical imaginations of pledges lead
to the attempted filching of a well-known flag on federal
property, however, the name and stature of the university is in jeopardy. The IFC acted swiftly and vigorously in penalizing the fraternity involved. We sympathize with the fraternity brothers of Phi Psi, who
have no control over the precocity of their pledges. But
we also realibe that this incident was harmful to the
fraternity system. The gravity of the situation demanded
swift action, and the IFC should be applauded for its
effort to preserve the healthy environment of fraternities at this university.

A,B,C,D,E,.•••
The current editors of the News-Letter feel that
letters to the editor should be printed if at all possible.
Because of space limitation this involves some discretion
in seleciton from time to time. Often there are no letters at all. On the occasions when the office is inundated
with letters, usually resulting from missteps in the previous issue, we try to print the most intelligible and controversial offerings.
News-Letter personnel in the past have expressed
opinions in the Correspondence that the co-editors did
not feel belonged in the editorial column. This has included criticism of the paper's own policy. We are not a
supermarket that prohibits employees from entering its
contests. As on any other newsaper, the News-Letter staff
does not often unanimously agree with its editors. Consequently, a student's campus affiliations, even if they
include this publication itself, are not valid reasons
in themselves for accepting or rejecting a letter. There

Hop History: Part V

Remsen, Educated As Doctor,
Installs Chemistry Department
By JAMES R. MEGINNISS
Ira Remsen, one day to be the
first professor of chemistry at the
Johns Hopkins University, was
forced by his father to study
medicine. So he did. Sent by his
father to the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia
University, he was graduated as
a doctor of medicine in 1867. For
a thesis, he wrote on the Fatty
Degeneration of the Liver.
Benjamin Harrow quotes Remsen as saying, eleven years later
In 1878,"My erudition in medical
matters was exhibited in a thesis
on the Fatty Degeneration of the
Liver, a subject on which I was
and am profoundly ignorant. I
had, in fact, never seen a liver
which had undergone fatty degeneration, nor a patient who
possessed, or was supposed to
possess one; nor, I may add,
have I had that pleasure up to
this day." Yet Remsen, marvelously enough, received one of the
two awards given for the best
thesis! Such was the incredible
state of medical education in the
U.S. at that time.
Remsen, as noted above, was
not cut out for medicine. What
little exposure he had had to
chemistry, up to his graduation
from medical school, had fascinated him. Remsen himself describes what might be called his
first chemical experiment, which
he performed when about 14
or 15:
"While reading a text-book of
chemistry I came upon the statement, 'nitric acid acts upon copper.' I was getting tired of reading such ab.surb stuff and I determined to see what this meant.
Copper was more or less familiar
to me, for copper cents were
then in use. I had seen a bottle
marked 'nitric acid' on a table
in the doctor's office where I
was then 'doing time.' I did not
know its peculiarities, but I was
getting on and likely to learn.
The spirit of adventure was upon
me.
Opened Bottle
"I . .
opened the bottle
marked 'nitric acid'; poured
some of the liquid on the copper; and prepared to take an
observation. But what was this
wonderful thing I beheld? The
cent was already changed, and it
was no small change either. A
greenish blue liquid foamed and
fumed over the cent and over
the table. The air in the neighborhood of the performance became colored dark red. A great
cloud arose. This was disagree-

able and suffocating. How should
I stop this?
"I tried to get rid of the
objectionable mass by picking it
up and throwing it out of the
window, which I had meanwhile
opened. I learned another fact—
nitric acid not only acts upon
copper but it acts upon fingers.
The pain led to another unpremeditated experiment. I drew
my fingers across my trousers
and another fact was discovered.
Nitric acid acts upon trousers."
Chemistry Studied
In 1867, Ira Remsen, M.D., set
out for Germany to study chemistry. He there studied under
Volhard and, later, Fittig, Five
years after arriving in Germany,
he had a Ph.D., considerable lecture and research experience,
and a ticket back to the U.S.:
but he had no university position

waiting for him. He had no
choice but to wait for an offer.
After long months of waiting,
he was finally offered the position
of Professor of Chemistry at
Williams College. When he arrived to take over his new position, he noticed that one thing
was missing—a chemistry laboratory! It took a year before he
could get the trustees to build
him one. During his four years
at Williams. Remsen wrote a
textbook, Theoretical Chemistry,
and did research on the action
of ozone on various substances.
Both his book and his research
were successful. The book went
through gve editions and was
translated into German and
Russian. The results of the research were published, and thus
came to the attention of Daniel

Doublecrossed
To the Editors:
Come one, come all to the new
Johns Hopkins Athletic Center.
Here folks, we also have the Lacrosse Hall of Fame. It's a great
honor to have this shrine here,
but Hopkins means Lacrosse all
over the country.
And, as you enter, on the
marble pedestals to your right
and left, are J.H.U.'s all time
Lacrosse greats, Jack Turnbull
and Don Kelly in full battle
dress.
But no, there's something
wrong. It's a discus thrower
looking down, and his cohort,
passing a baton? In front of our
new building? In front of the
Lacrosse Hall of Fame? Never!
But there they are.

In the market for a professor of

University. And so it was that,
at age thirty, Ira Remsen gave
up his position at Williams and
came to Hopkins.
Professor At Hopkins
As a professor at Hopkins,
Remsen was told by Gilman to
"Do your best work and to do
It in your own way." There were
no other restrictions.
During the quarter century of
Professorship which followed,
Remsen contributed to chemical
knowledge. He was co-discoverer
of saccharin in 1879, working
with a graduate student by the
name of Fahlberg. Remsen also
did much other important work
In organic chemistry.
In 1879, to meet the needs of
American chemistry, he founded
the American Medical Journal.
This journal was published until
1914, when its function as the
medium for chemical research in
America had been adequately
taken over by the Journal of the
American Medical Society.
Concerning Ira Remsen, Dr.
Benjamin Harrow writes in Eminent Chemists: "As teacher, as
research worker, and as a writer
of eight textbooks) he is more
directly responsible for the development of the science (chemistry) in the United States than
any other man."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 14, 1965

Cinde.rmen Send Eight
To M-D Championships
Despite its winless record, the
varsity track team sends some
potent individual performers into the Mason-Dixon Championships today and tomorrow at Old
Dominion.
Slated by Coach Ed Polanowski to make the trip are hurdler
Mike Fauntleroy; shot and discus men Steve Layton, Dave
Fiske, and Lee Dellon; highjumper Pete Rowney; pole vaulter Rubin Aaronsen; and distance
runners Kevin Murphy and John
Sopka.
Potential Champ
Murphy, a junior, finished
third in the two mile run at the
championships last year, and is
tabbed by Polanowski as potentially one of the finest runners in
the school's history. The squad's
only other performer of note in
the '64 meet is Fauntleroy, who
placed in the 330 hurdles.
Looking over the team's 0-6
log, the varsity coach was quick
to point out that the Jays
dropped some close decisions,

most notably 75-70 and 74-70
losses to Western Maryland and
Washington. He also noted that
one school record had fallen this
season, as Steve Layton set a
new mark in the javelin.
"I'm hopeful of better things
next year," said Polanowski,
"since we're losing only three
boys through graduation and
have a fairly good group of
freshmen coming up, among
them four or five boys who could
be really good."
Frosh Attitude
Taking a further look at the
frosh, he felt that only lack of
a really good attitude kept them
from being outstanding and
blamed their 1-3 mark on some
lackadaisical performances.
On that team, Polanowski cited
especially Bo Walker and Clifford Cyr. Cyr was noted as a top
competitor in the distance events
and Walker has won 18 of 20
events he has been entered in in
four meets.

over Phi Sig to clinch the fraternity title. The Gams are 9-0,
while second-place ATO, which
meets DU, is 8-1.
In other games ZBT faces
AEPi, AD tackles Phi Ep, and
KA challenges Phi Psi. The
standings so far are as follows:
Phi Gam, 9-0; ATO, 8-1; DU,
6-2; Phi Sig, 7-3; Beta, 6-3.
Also, Sig Ep, 44; Phi Psi, 3-3;
Phi Ep, 3-5; AEPi, 2-5; KA, 1-7;
and AD, 0-9.
Tuesday's stick clashes found
Phi Gam beating DU and Phi Ep
losing to ATO.
In League A softball ZBT is
the leader, boasting a 5-0 record.

Trailing them are DU, 4-1; ATO,
2-2; AD, 2-2; Sig Ep, 1-3; and
Phi Gam, 0-5. Phi Sig and Phi
Psi, both unbeaten, lead League
B.
With final games posted for
Sunday, Griffin leads frosh softball with a 4-0 log. Baker is 3-1;
Gildersleeve, 3-1; Jennings is
2-2; Adams, 1-3; and Clark, 1-3.
Among upperclass dorms Royce
is 4-0, Lazear, 3-1; Wood, 3-1;
Sylvester, 2-2; Wilson and Willard both 0-4.

Coach Wilson Fewster's freshman lacrosse team put the
brakes on a previously unbeaten
Maryland frosh contingent Friday, stopping the Terps 13-10.,
The win, in the Jays' final tilt,
left them 4-2.
Joe Cowan led Hopkins in
scoring against Maryland, which
earlier had beaten the Navy
Plebes. The midfielder had four
goals and all of his squad's six
assists.
Also in the scoring column for
that encounter was Phil Kneip,
with five goals: Bob Carter, with
three; and Downy McCarty, with

year, while Berlin had never before played goalie. "Berlin was

and fine stickwork.

Lose To Navy
Concerning his team's loss to
National Champions Navy, the
coach just pointed to the statistics of the game.'They had fourteen out of sixteen face-offs in
the first half. We were able to
pick up only 38 ground balls,
while Navy managed to gather
61. However, we did manage to
get off 42 shots compared to
Navy's 56."
Navy jumped out to a 1-0 lead

with a goal by Lewis. Stan Fine
tied the score with a shot bouncing off the inside section of the
upper pipe, but the Midshipmen
rammed in three straight goals
to take the lead for good.
Using their superior height and
speed to its greatest advantage,
the Middies played a control-type
ball game, continually putting
pressure on the Jay defense. On
situation and extra man plays
the Midshipmen were deadly.
The big scorer for Hopkins was
Ray Gordon with two goals and
one assist. Fine had two goals,
Jerry Schnydman one goal and
an assist, Skip Darrell a goal,
and Joe Blattner one assist.

SCOPE Publishes Projects List
Under CORE, SOS Sponsors
For Summer Project Workers
By GARTH MacKENZIE
In the past five years a constantly increasing number of
college students have become involved in community service
projects throughout the United
States.
Student organizations on
American campuses are beginning to demonstrate a greater
concern for the social, economic,
and political affairs of the country and its citizens, as compared
to the general apathy which existed in the schools a decade ago.
This summer, under the auspices of organizations such as
the Congress for Racial Equality,
Students for a Democratic Society, the American Friends Service Committee, and the National
Catholic
Welfare
Conference,
college students will be serving
communities as social workers,
tutors, and guides.
In order to provide an authoratative, impartial journal listing

The U.S. Navy Marine Engineering Laboratory conducts RDT&E in naval shipboard and submarine machinery
& auxiliary systems (electrical, propulsion, control, etc.). In addition to developing basic improvements
in performance and reliability, the Laboratory concentrates on ship silencing, new concepts in energy conversion and control, ways to minimize friction and wear, special operating machinery for deep-diving vessels;
and tough, resistant naval alloys to meet all ocean environmental conditions.
The Laboratory buildings—now more than 50 of them—house some of the finest research, experimental
and evaluation equipments of their kind ... such as high-speed computers, electric power generators, vibration and shock test stands, metals composition analysis instruments, cryogenic storage and handling facilities,
physics and chemistry labs, and complex instrumentation for measuring strain, stress, pressure, acceleration,
velocity, performance, and reliability. The Laboratory grounds resemble a modern industrial park, and
include special facilities for in-field experimentation.
Because of a sharply increased workload involving urgent new projects, there are key openings for qualified professionals in every MEL division ... Electrical Systems, Machinery Systems, Ship Silencing, Friction St Wear, Naval Alloys, and Special Projects.

The American Way
The Johnson Administration has adopted the nasty
habit of presenting United States' activities on the world
scene as faits accomplis. The President is supposedly
sensitive to campus opinion, but it is now often hard for
even resourceful students and professors to get facts to
have opinions about. When they finally do get them,
they are no longer applicable to the situation.
Who knows the Administration's rationale for
bombing North Vietnam? It used to be because the North
was actively aiding the Viet Cong in the South (a contention our Government attempted to prove after the
raids began) and this was a measure to curtail that aid.
Today the Administration admits that the raids are of
minimal value in performing this function. Who knows
what the current reason is? The Marines went into
Santo Domingo with the avowed intention of establishing
a demilitarized zone to protect our citizens. This itself,
humane though it might be, is a violation of the OAS
Charter the United States so enthusiastically promoted.
Within a week our forces had moved out of this zone
into direct confrontation with the rebels. Why was this
done?
The question of who is right in Vietnam or Santo
Domingo is not at issue here. What is at issue is how a
democratic government justifies partially or wholly
concealing basic policies from its citzens. What is the
purpose of delaying the public announcement of motives
and non-secret facts (e.g. Communists have taken over
the Dominican revolution) until after the die is cast?
It is very dangerous to have history written even a
week in advance.

Old Glory
Fraternity pranks are normally of a fairly innocuous
nature and can he condoned as one of the traditions,
either positive or negative, of the fraternity pledge
period. Whn the whimsical imaginations of pledges lead
to the attempted filching of a well-known flag on federal
property, however, the name and stature of the university is in jeopardy. The IFC acted swiftly and vigorously in penalizing the fraternity involved. We sympathize with the fraternity brothers of Phi Psi, who
have no control over the precocity of their pledges. But
we also realibe that this incident was harmful to the
fraternity system. The gravity of the situation demanded
swift action, and the IFC should be applauded for its
effort to preserve the healthy environment of fraternities at this university.

The current editors of the News-Letter feel that
letters to the editor should be printed if at all possible.
Because of space limitation this involves some discretion
in seleciton from time to time. Often there are no letters at all. On the occasions when the office is inundated
with letters, usually resulting from missteps in the previous issue, we try to print the most intelligible and controversial offerings.
News-Letter personnel in the past have expressed
opinions in the Correspondence that the co-editors did
not feel belonged in the editorial column. This has included criticism of the paper's own policy. We are not a
supermarket that prohibits employees from entering its
contests. As on any other newsaper, the News-Letter staff
does not often unanimously agree with its editors. Consequently, a student's campus affiliations, even if they
include this publication itself, are not valid reasons
in themselves for accepting or rejecting a letter. There
is likewise no a priori taboo on subject matter.

Hop History: Part V

Remsen, Educated As Doctor,
Installs Chemistry Department
By JAMES R. MEGINNISS
Ira Remsen, one day to be the
first professor of chemistry at the
Johns Hopkins University, was
forced by his father to study
medicine. So he did. Sent by his
father to the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia
University, he was graduated as
a doctor of medicine in 1867. For
a thesis, he wrote on the Fatty
Degeneration of the Liver.
Benjamin Harrow quotes Remsen as saying, eleven years later
In 1878,"My erudition in medical
matters was exhibited in a thesis
on the Fatty Degeneration of the
Liver, a subject on which I was
and am profoundly ignorant. I
had, in fact, never seen a liver
which had undergone fatty degeneration, nor a patient who
possessed, or was supposed to
possess one; nor, I may add,
have I had that pleasure up to
this day." Yet Remsen, marvelously enough, received one of the
two awards given for the best
thesis! Such was the incredible
state of medical education in the
U.S. at that time.
Remsen, as noted above, was
not cut out for medicine. What
little exposure he had had to
chemistry, up to his graduation
from medical school, had fascinated him. Remsen himself describes what might be called his
first chemical experiment, which
he performed when about 14
or 15:
"While reading a text-book of
chemistry I came upon the statement, 'nitric acid acts upon copper.' I was getting tired of reading such ab.surb stuff and I determined to see what this meant.
Copper was more or less familiar
to me, for copper cents were
then in use. I had seen a bottle
marked 'nitric acid' on a table
in the doctor's office where I
was then 'doing time.' I did not
know its peculiarities, but I was
getting on and likely to learn.
The spirit of adventure was upon
me.
Opened Bottle
"I . .
opened the bottle
marked 'nitric acid'; poured
some of the liquid on the copper; and prepared to take an
observation. But what was this
wonderful thing I beheld? The
cent was already changed, and it
was no small change either. A
greenish blue liquid foamed and
fumed over the cent and over
the table. The air in the neighborhood of the performance became colored dark red. A great
cloud arose. This was disagree-

able and suffocating. How should
I stop this?
"I tried to get rid of the
objectionable mass by picking it
up and throwing it out of the
window, which I had meanwhile
opened. I learned another fact—
nitric acid not only acts upon
copper but it acts upon fingers.
The pain led to another unpremeditated experiment. I drew
my fingers across my trousers
and another fact was discovered.
Nitric acid acts upon trousers."
Chemistry Studied
In 1867, Ira Remsen, M.D., set
out for Germany to study chemistry. He there studied under
Volhard and, later, Fittig, Five
years after arriving in Germany,
he had a Ph.D., considerable lecture and research experience,
and a ticket back to the U.S.:
but he had no university position

waiting for him. He had no
choice but to wait for an offer.
After long months of waiting,
he was finally offered the position
of Professor of Chemistry at
Williams College. When he arrived to take over his new position, he noticed that one thing
was missing—a chemistry laboratory! It took a year before he
could get the trustees to build
him one. During his four years
at Williams. Remsen wrote a
textbook, Theoretical Chemistry,
and did research on the action
of ozone on various substances.
Both his book and his research
were successful. The book went
through gve editions and was
translated into German and
Russian. The results of the research were published, and thus
came to the attention of Daniel

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAY 14, 1965

Cinde.rmen Send Eight
To M-D Championships
Despite its winless record, the
varsity track team sends some
potent individual performers into the Mason-Dixon Championships today and tomorrow at Old
Dominion.
Slated by Coach Ed Polanowski to make the trip are hurdler
Mike Fauntleroy; shot and discus men Steve Layton, Dave
Fiske, and Lee Dellon; highjumper Pete Rowney; pole vaulter Rubin Aaronsen; and distance
runners Kevin Murphy and John
Sopka.
Potential Champ
Murphy, a junior, finished
third in the two mile run at the
championships last year, and is
tabbed by Polanowski as potentially one of the finest runners in
the school's history. The squad's
only other performer of note in
the '64 meet is Fauntleroy, who
placed in the 330 hurdles.
Looking over the team's 0-6
log, the varsity coach was quick
to point out that the Jays
dropped some close decisions,

most notably 75-70 and 74-70
losses to Western Maryland and
Washington. He also noted that
one school record had fallen this
season, as Steve Layton set a
new mark in the javelin.
"I'm hopeful of better things
next year," said Polanowski,
"since we're losing only three
boys through graduation and
have a fairly good group of
freshmen coming up, among
them four or five boys who could
be really good."
Frosh Attitude
Taking a further look at the
frosh, he felt that only lack of
a really good attitude kept them
from being outstanding and
blamed their 1-3 mark on some
lackadaisical performances.
On that team, Polanowski cited
especially Bo Walker and Clifford Cyr. Cyr was noted as a top
competitor in the distance events
and Walker has won 18 of 20
events he has been entered in in
four meets.
